Other processes are summarized in Table S3 and Table S4 in Supplementary Information [
Lithiumand manganese were recovered fromspent LIBs with nitric acid by Castillo et al. without
the addition of a reducing agent [
]. In this process, cobalt, nickel, andiron remain in the solidresidue,
whereas manganese hydroxide is precipitated from the leaching solution with NaOH. The addition
of a reducing agent helped to increase leaching of cobalt and nickel as demonstrated by Guan et al.
]. As for other inorganic acids, H
is the most popular reducing agent.
Additionally, Guan et al. demonstrated the e
ciency of galvanic reduction of transition metals using
iron powder during a mechano-chemical leaching. However, this process su
L) and the relatively slow kinetics compared with other processes.
Furthermore, nitric acid seems to be ine
cient for LFP dissolution without the addition of H
shown by Wu et al. and Yang et al. [
]. Asummary of the nitric acid systemis presented in Tables
S5 and S6 in Supplementary Materials. The nitric acid leaching reaction proposed by Zeng et al. is as
], but it may be questioned for its accuracy considering the oxidizing character of nitric acid.
The recovery of valuable element(s) fromnitrate solution is generally done by precipitation and
]. More speciﬁcally, Moura et al. proposed the coprecipitation
with ferric chloride, ammonium hydroxide, and ammonium
acetate. The solid product required calcination at 450
C to obtain Co doped ferrite. Finally, this
product served as a catalyst for destroying methylene blue, which is a major contaminant in the textile
uent. Yang et al. obtained by precipitation a high performance NMC active material
g), but showing a lowstability under cycling (81.2%capacity retention after 100 cycles) [
Cobalt electrodeposition was successfully applied by Li et al. and Myoung et al. [
The former synthesized fresh LCOmaterial fromthe nitrate leach solution alkalized to pH
MLiOHby applying a current of 1 mA
between a Ni anode and a Pt cathode [
. The mechanism of the ﬁlm formation proposed by Li et al. followed an
electro-hydrothermal pathway. At high pH, the suspended Co(OH)
which migrated to the positive electrode (nickel anode). In the vicinity of the anode, oxyhydroxide
ions accumulated upon reaching the saturation concentration, thereby promoting precipitation of
on the Ni electrode. Application of a small current oxidized the divalent Co to trivalent
, which is lithiated by following spontaneous reaction:
However, the resulting active material showed low energetic capacity, with a ﬁrst discharge at
g at 0.1 C while the theoretical capacity of fresh LCO can reach 140 mAh
